text: today on the caucus john harwood and
jackie comms discussed the rhetoric and
the reality of the budget battles in
washington so Jackie Tim Geithner the
Treasury secretary says we have now
reached the statutory debt limit on the
other hand they say they can fudge it
until August what does this mean well
they've got all sorts of ways of money
management ways of moving you know not
paying certain bills they've estimated
that can take him till about August
second so that gives us the summer to
fight about it help decode a little bit
whether or not in fact this is a titanic
fight or whether it's same old same old
hard to know whether to be sad when or
whether to expect a right can I say it's
a little of both yeah he's same old same
old in the sense that the Democrats are
not for doing it all on the spending
side all the savings that is the
Republicans want it to all be spending
cuts no tax increases but what makes
this Titanic is that we're talking about
numbers that are so much larger than any
we've ever seen before I was struck by
looking at the history at just how
partisan it is all the members of one
party if their presidents in power they
vote to support him on the debt limit
and they take a walk if they're the
other parties in power right exactly
it'd be funny if it wasn't so serious
the Republicans in the Senate can afford
to vote no but that Republicans run the
house so they have responsibility along
with the power at a similar moment the
1980s Congress passed what they called
the Graham Rudman Hollings law which
began a process of deficit reduction
that ultimately led to a balanced budget
although it didn't immediately can that
kind of process which is a model for
what the they're negotiating today work
now by setting targets deficit targets
that they have to meet the hope is that
you know you leave it to Congress how
and the White House how you're going to
you know do spending and revenues in
order to hit those targets if you don't
what happens in the 80s and the 90s
would presumably recur which is you go
to the negotiating table and you really
bear down and try to come up with if not
the exact targets then new targets but
that
progress so it sounds like what we're
doing right now is not a process that
will end in the next few months but we
are beginning the long process turning
the fiscal ship negotiating toward a
solution sometime in the future I think
the way to think of this is to is in to
two prongs one there will be specific
spending cuts that would take that there
would be identified and would take place
over the next ten years and certainly in
the next year and then number two
there'd be this process that would set
these deficit targets to meet that would
be a way of ensuring that additional
savings will be found in the coming
years John Boehner the Speaker said over
the weekend that there's no need to go
to the 11th hour on this we can do this
early any prospect that that will happen
or is this a process that by its nature
always goes to the 11th hour human
nature always cooks to the last hour and
especially the humans in Congress
